skill.name: reflect-on-work
skill.description: Pattern for producing quality reflections after completing work. Required for all agent outputs.
skill.summary: Pattern for producing quality reflections after completing work. Required for all agent outputs.
skill.author: Clouder0

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill is a documentation and reflection pattern template. Network/filesystem flags are legitimate GitHub URL metadata. External command flags are triggered by code block backticks in documentation examples. JWT reference is example text, not cryptographic code.

content.value_statement: Agents often complete tasks without documenting insights. This skill provides a structured pattern for capturing knowledge updates, reflection fields, and lessons learned after every task.
actual_capabilities: Generate structured reflection output after task completion
Capture knowledge updates with category and confidence levels
Document what worked, what failed, and patterns noticed
Produce compact JSON output compatible with agent systems
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Requires agent to invoke the reflection pattern manually
Output format is JSON, not natural language summaries
Does not persist reflections to external storage systems

use_cases.title: Capture Learning After Code Reviews
use_cases.description: After reviewing or modifying code, capture structural insights, conventions discovered, and gotchas encountered to build codebase understanding.
use_cases.target_user: Software developers using Claude for code review

use_cases.title: Document Workflow Effectiveness
use_cases.description: After completing development tasks, reflect on which strategies succeeded and which failed to improve future agent performance.

use_cases.title: Build Knowledge Base Systematically
use_cases.description: Every task generates knowledge updates that contribute to a growing understanding of the project structure and patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Reflection
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete your task and provide a reflection. Include knowledge_updates with one item (category: codebase|convention|decision|gotcha, content: your insight, confidence: certain|likely|uncertain) and reflection with what_worked, what_failed, and patterns_noticed arrays.
prompt_templates.scenario: Standard task completion with minimal reflection

prompt_templates.title: Detailed Reflection
prompt_templates.prompt: After completing your work, produce reflection with at least 3 knowledge_updates covering different categories. For reflection, list at least 2 items in each field: what_worked, what_failed, patterns_noticed. Output as compact single-line JSON.
prompt_templates.scenario: Comprehensive task debrief with deep insights

prompt_templates.title: Learning Focused Reflection
prompt_templates.prompt: Focus your reflection on learning. Document new conventions discovered, design decisions you encountered, and any gotchas or pitfalls to avoid. Rate your confidence for each knowledge_update based on verification level.
prompt_templates.scenario: Emphasizing knowledge capture over task completion

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Mining Reflection
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete the task, then focus your reflection on patterns_noticed. What recurring structures, code patterns, or workflow improvements did you observe? Include at least 3 specific patterns with examples.
prompt_templates.scenario: Extracting reusable patterns from task experience

output_examples.input: You fixed a bug in the authentication module
output: Task completed. Reflection:
Knowledge Updates:
- convention: Auth module uses JWT tokens for session management (certain)
- gotcha: Must call init() before using AuthService (certain)
What Worked:
- Found similar patterns in existing codebase quickly
- Starting with types helped structure the fix
What Failed:
- Initial approach missed edge case with refresh tokens
- Spent time on wrong file before checking auth module
Patterns Noticed:
- All services use dependency injection
- Error handling always uses Result type pattern

output_examples.input: You explored a new codebase to understand its structure
output: Reflection:
Knowledge Updates:
- codebase: API routes follow /api/v1/{resource} pattern (certain)
- convention: Project uses barrel exports in each directory (certain)
- decision: Controllers are separated from routes (likely)
What Worked:
- Parallel file explorers found context quickly
- Starting with entry points revealed architecture
What Failed:
- Initial test approach was wrong for this codebase
- Tried to understand routing before controllers
Patterns Noticed:
- Tests are colocated with source files
- Configuration uses environment variables extensively

best_practices: Include at least one knowledge_update per task to build project understanding over time
Rate confidence accurately: certain for verified facts, likely for strong evidence, uncertain for observations needing confirmation
Be specific in reflection fields with concrete examples rather than generic statements
anti_patterns: Leaving reflection arrays empty defeats the purpose of knowledge capture
Using vague terms like things or stuff instead of specific insights
Skipping reflection when tasks fail, since failures contain valuable learning opportunities

faq.question: What is the purpose of this skill?
faq.answer: This skill provides a structured pattern for agents to reflect after completing work. It captures knowledge updates and lessons learned to improve future performance and build project understanding.

faq.question: When should I use the knowledge_update categories?
faq.answer: Use codebase for structural discoveries, convention for style and patterns, decision for design choices, and gotcha for pitfalls and workarounds. Choose the category that best fits your insight.

faq.question: How should I choose confidence levels?
faq.answer: Use certain when you verified the information through code inspection or testing. Use likely when you have strong evidence but did not directly confirm. Use uncertain for observations that need future verification.

faq.question: Can I skip reflection for simple tasks?
faq.answer: Even simple tasks may reveal insights. At minimum, provide empty arrays rather than skipping the reflection entirely. This maintains consistent output format and captures any unexpected discoveries.

faq.question: How does this skill integrate with other Claude skills?
faq.answer: This skill can be invoked after any task completion. The JSON output format is designed to be compatible with task management systems and knowledge bases that accept structured reflection data.

faq.question: What makes a good patterns_noticed entry?
faq.answer: Good pattern entries are specific and reusable. Include the pattern name, where it was observed, and how it can be applied. Avoid generic statements like found a pattern without details.
